finding: This study found that vaccination against influenza increases the expression of the regulatory T cell (Treg) marker, Foxp3, in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) of healthy volunteers.

The study also revealed that vaccination leads to an increase in the antibody titers against the influenza A (H1N1) virus and the influenza B virus, as well as an increase in the production of cytokines, such as IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, and IFN-γ, in the plasma of the vaccinated individuals.
The study found that the expression of the Treg marker, Foxp3, in CD4+CD25+ PBMCs is associated with an increased production of IL-10, a cytokine that is known to suppress inflammation.
The study also found that the expression of CD127, another Treg marker, was increased in PBMCs after vaccination, suggesting an increase in Treg cells.

The study noted that the expression of CD127 and Foxp3 in Treg cells was associated with an increase in the production of IL-10 and a decrease in the production of IFN-γ, which is associated with Th1 cells and is known to be involved in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases.
